newsitem.title: FRANCE: French air traffic hit by lingering strikes.
newsitem.headline: French air traffic hit by lingering strikes.

text.p: Air France Europe cancelled about 40 percent of its flights on Monday as pilots extended a strike that began last Friday over terms of its merger with parent company Air France.
The pilots were set to hold a meeting on the future of their movement on Monday afternoon.

Service at British Airways' French units TAT and Air Liberte returned gradually to normal on Monday as pilots went back to work. The airlines predicted minor disruption would continue due to a strike by flight attendants.
The flight attendants were protesting against what they say are unacceptable conditions of a merger between the two airlines.
Air traffic controllers at Paris Orly airport gave notice they would strike on April 30 to gain work conditions similar to their counterparts at Charles de Gaulle Roissy airport.
A spokesman for France's aviation authority could not give precise figures about the expected level of disruption but said at least 40 percent of scheduled traffic would be assured.

The 120 Orly air traffic controllers say the level of traffic at Paris' smaller airport, though less than at Roissy, is high enough to warrant similar treatment in terms of bonuses and pay differentials.
The aviation authority was ready to open negotiations on the issue, the spokesman said.
